chapterTitle: Financial Statements, Taxes, and Cash Flow

columns.text: This exercise requires us to compute the net income, operating cash flow, cash flow from assets, cash flow to creditors and cash flow to shareholders.

Let's first define the important terms in the problem.

- **Net income** is the business income after subtracting all of its expenses for the period.

- **Operating Cash Flow** measures the amount of cash generated by a company's normal business operation.

- **Cash flow from assets** is the total of all cash flows relating to company's assets.

- **Cash Flow to Creditors** is the amount of money that is paid to the debt holders during an accounting period.

- **Cash flow to Shareholders** is the amount of money that passes to shareholders in the form of dividends after new equity is deducted.

Let's identify the given amounts in the problem.


| |2017 ($)|2018 ($) |
|--|--:| --:| 
|Sales  | |33,106 |
|Cost of goods sold | |23,624 |
|Depreciation Expense | |5,877| 
|Interest expense | |2,650| 
|Dividends paid | |1,888| 
|Net fixed assets |19,820 | 24,394|
| Current assets |6,970 |8,612 |
|Current liabilities |3,920 |4,575 |

The tax rate for 2018 was 22%.

### a. Net income for 2018

To calculate the net income of the company, we can prepare an income statement. In preparing an income statement, it is important to use this formula:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Net Income} &= \text{Sales} - {\text{Expenses}}\\[1pt]
\end{aligned}$$

The income statement presents different stages such as gross profit, earnings before taxes, taxable income and net income.

Now, we can compute the net income for 2018 using the presented income statement below:

$$\def\arraystretch{1.2} 
\begin{array}{|c|} \hline 
\textbf{Cardinal Industries}\\ 
\text{Income Statement}\\ 
\text{For the year ended December 31, 2018}\\ \hline 
\begin{array}{l r r }\\ \text{Sales} & \$\hspace{7pt}33,106&\\ 
\text{Less: Cost of Sales} & \underline{23,624} & \\ 
\textbf{Gross Profit} & \$\hspace{9pt}9,482\\ 
\text{Less: Depreciation} & \underline{\quad 5,877} &\\ 
\textbf{Earnings before interest and taxes} & \$\hspace{7pt}3,605\\ 
\text{Interest Expense} & \underline{2,650}\\ 
\textbf{Taxable income} & {{\mathbf{\$\hspace{13pt}955}}}\\ 
\text{Tax Expense} & \underline{\hspace{25pt}210}\\ 
\textbf{Net income} & \underline{\underline{\mathbf{\$\hspace{13pt}745}}}\\ \end{array}\\\\ \hline 
\end{array}$$

Therefore, the net income for 2018 of Raines Umbrella Corp. is **$745**.

### b. Operating Cash Flow

Operating Cash Flow is computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Operating Cash Flow} &= \text{EBIT} + {\text{Depreciation}} - {\text{Taxes}}\\[1pt] \end{aligned}$$
​

Now that we have computed the EBIT in step, let's now compute for the operating cash flow using the equation in step 5.

$$\begin{aligned} 
\text{Operating Cash Flow} &= \text{EBIT} + {\text{Depreciation}} - {\text{Taxes}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{\$3,605} + {\text{5,877}} - {\text{210}}\\[5pt] 
&= \underline{\underline{\textbf{\$9,272}}} 
\end{aligned}$$

Therefore, the operating cash flow of Cardinal Industries is **$9,272**.

### c. Cash Flow from Assets

Cash flow from assets is computed as follows:

$$\begin {array}{lrr} 
\text{Operating Cash Flow}&\$\hspace{10pt}\text{xx}\\ 
\text{Less: Change in Net Working Capital}&{\text{xx}}\\ 
\text{Less: Net Capital Spending​}&\underline{\text{xx}}&\\ 
\textbf{Cash flow from assets}&\underline{\underline{\$\hspace{5pt}\textbf{xx}}}\\ \end{array}

Before we compute for the cash flow from assets, we need to compute first the change in net working capital using the formula below:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{Change in NWC} &= \text{NWC, 2018} -{\text{NWC, 2017}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{(CA, 2018 - CL, 2018)} -{\text{(CA, 2017 - CL, 2017)}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{(8,612 - 4,575)} -{\text{(6,970 - 3,920)}}\\[5pt]
&= \text{\$4,037} - {\text{3,050}}\\[5pt] 
&= \underline{\underline{\text{\$987}}}
 \end{aligned}

Next, we will compute the net capital spending as shown below:

$$\begin{aligned} \text{NCS} &= \text{NFA 2018} - {\text{NFA 2017}} + {\text{Depreciation}}\\[5pt] 
&= \text{24,394} - {\text{19,820}} + {\text{5,877}}\\[5pt] 
&= \underline{\underline{\text{\$10,451}}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

NCS = Net Capital Spending
NFA = Net Fixed Asset
Therefore, the cash flow to creditors is **$2,650** while cash flow to shareholders is **- $4,816.**

Let's now interpret the results above:

a. The net income of the company is **positive** because the company's sales exceed the total expense incurred.

b. The company has a **positive** operative cash flow, indicating that the company's operations are doing well and profitable.

c. The cash from assets of the company is **negative**. This indicates that the company made significant investments in fixed assets and net working capital.

d. The company has a **positive** cash flow to creditors but a **negative** cash flow to shareholders. To cover the negative cash flow to shareholders, the company needed to raise $2,166 from its shareholders.
In this problem, we are required to determine the net income, operating cash flow, cash flow from assets, cash flow to creditors, and cash flow to stockholders for Cardinal Industries.

Before we begin, let us first define cash flow:

**Cash flow** is the net amount of cash and cash equivalents moving in and out of a company during a period of time.

## a. Net income for 2018

The net income for 2018 can be computed as follows:

$$ 
\bold{Cardinal~Industries}\\ 
\bold{Income~Statement}\\ 
\bold{For~ the ~Year~ Ended~ 2018}\\ $$

$$\begin{array}{cccc}\\
\begin{aligned}
&\text{Sales}&&&\text{\$33,106.00}&\\
&\text{Less: Cost of Goods Sold}&&&\text{23,624.00}&\\
&\text{ Depreciation}&&&\underline{\text{~~~~~~~~5,877.00}}&\\
&\text{EBIT}&&&{\$~3,605.00}\\ 
&\text{Less: Interest}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~2,650.00}&\\
&\text{EBT}&&&955.00&\\
&\text{Less: Taxes (22\%)}&&&\underline{~~~~~~~~~~210.10}&\\
&\bold{Net~Income}&&&{\boxed{\bold{\$~744.90}}}\\

\end{aligned}
\end{array}$$
\
The net income for 2018 is $744.90.

## b. Operating cash flow for 2018

Operating cash flow for 2018 should be computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Operating cash flow}& = \text{EBIT + Depreciation - Taxes}\\ \\
&=\$3,605.00 + \$5,877.00 -  \$210.10\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$9,271.90}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the operating cash flow for 2018 is $9,271.90.

## c. Cash flow from assets for 2018

Before we can determine the cash flow from assets, first we need to determine the net capital spending:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Net Fixed Assets, Ending}& \$24,394\\
\text{Less: Net Fixed Assets, Beginning} & 19,820\\
\text{Add: Depreciation} & 5,877\\  \hline
\textbf{Net Capital Spending}&\boxed{\$10,451}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Next is to determine the changes in net working capital at the beginning of the year:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current Assets}& \$6,970\\
\text{Less: Current Liabilities} & 3,920\\ \hline
\textbf{Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$3,050}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Next is to determine the changes in net working capital at the end of the year:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Current Assets}& \$8,612\\
\text{Less: Current Liabilities} & 4,575\\ \hline
\textbf{Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$4,037}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Now we can already determine changes in net working capital:

$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Net Working Capital, end}& \$4,037\\
\text{Less: Net Working Capital, beginning} & 3,050\\ \hline
\textbf{Changes in Net Working Capital}&\boxed{\$987}\\ \\
\end{array}$$

Finally, to determine the cash flow from assets for 2018:
$$\begin{array}{l r}\\
\text{Operating cash flow}& \$9,271.90\\
\text{Less: Net Capital Spending} & 10,451.00\\ 
\text{Less: Changes in Net Working Capital} & 987.00\\ \hline
\textbf{Cash flow from assets}&\boxed{(\$2,166.10)}\\ \\
\end{array}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow from assets for 2018 is ($2,166.10).

The cash flow from assets shows whether the firm raised funds or distributed funds on a net basis, so this can either be positive or negative. Since the cash flow from assets is negative, this means that Cardinal Industries invested heavily in both fixed assets and net working capital. It also means that they need an additional $2,166 to make these investments.

## d. Cash flow to creditors 

Since there is no new debt was issued during the year, the cash flow to creditors can be computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash flow to creditors}& = \text{Interest paid - Net new borrowing} \\ \\
&=\$2,650 - \$0\\ \\
&=\boxed{\$2,650}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow to creditors is $2,650.

## Cash flow to stockholders 

 The cash flow to stockholders  can be computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Cash flow to stockholders}& = \text{Cash flow from assets - Cash flow to creditors} \\ \\
&=(\$2,166.10) - \$2,650.00 \\ \\
&=\boxed{(\$4,816.10)}\\
\end{aligned}$$
\
In conclusion, the cash flow to stockholders for 2018 is ($4,816.10).

We can also determine the net new equity:

$$\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Net New Equity}& = \text{Dividends paid - Cash flow to stockholders} \\ \\
&=\$1,888.00 - (\$4,816.10) \\ \\
&=\boxed{\$6,704.10}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Cardinal Industries has positive earnings and positive cash flow from operations. The company invested $987 in new net working capital and $10,451 in new fixed assets. The company needed to raise $2,166 from its stockholders to support its new investment. 

The company raised $6,704.10 in the form of new equity. After paying out dividends amounting to $1,888 and $2,650 to its creditors, $2,166.10 was left to meet the firm's cash flow needs for investment.

textbook.authors: Bradford D. Jordan, Randolph W. Westerfield, Stephen A. Ross
textbook.title: Fundamentals of Corporate Finance
